title: ‘If there’s a bubble, Tesla is it’: Carmaker soars on hopes for Musk’s robot push
text:
Tesla shares are on a tear, sending the electric carmaker’s chief executive Elon Musk half-way to becoming the world’s first trillionaire. But will the upcoming third-quarter sales figures be strong enough to sustain the momentum?

The stock rallied 33 per cent in September, notching their best month in almost a year, as investors rallied around Musk’s renewed focus on the company. Overnight, they jumped another 3.3 per cent, making the billionaire the first-ever person worth $US500 billion ($756 billion) , according to Forbes’ Real-Time Billionaires tracker.

Even more striking is Tesla’s ascent in the market since hitting a low in early April after US President Donald Trump paused his sweeping global tariffs. Since then, the share price has doubled, making it the best performer in the high-flying big tech cohort known as the Magnificent Seven.

The bet on Tesla is that Elon Musk can transform it from a car maker into an AI powerhouse. Credit: AP

The bet on Tesla is that Musk can transform it from a car manufacturer into an artificial intelligence powerhouse that makes robots and self-driving taxis. That goal is reflected in the unprecedented $US1 trillion pay package the company’s board proposed for Musk earlier this month.

title: The world-renowned Australian designer you’ve never heard of
text:
As origin stories go, Silvana Azzi Heras has a pretty good one. She was in her final year of her Bachelor of Design at the University of Western Sydney, as it was then known, when her lecturer contacted her about some work with a relatively new designer, Catherine Martin.

It was the mid-1990s and Martin and her husband, Baz Luhrmann, had enjoyed considerable success with his directorial debut film, Strictly Ballroom (including awards for best costume design and best production design), and the couple was about to start the publicity tour for his next offering, Romeo+Juliet. It was clear their stars were on the rise – and that Martin needed more help.

Silvana Azzi Heras in her studio at home in the inner west. Credit: Steven Siewert

So, she called the university and asked for recommendations for a couple of the best students in the course. Azzi Heras’ name was put forward.

“That weekend, my dad brought my little Apple computer over to Iona in Darlinghurst [where the couple lived] to help out CM,” she says.

title: SingTel rings up no tax as miners and banks support the budget
text:
The parent company of beleaguered telco company Optus failed to pay any corporate tax despite earning more than $8.2 billion in income from Australian customers, as new figures reveal that the federal budget increasingly depends on miners and banks.

The Australian Tax Office this morning released its annual corporate tax report that outlines the income and tax paid by the nation’s largest private and public companies. In 2023-24, more than 4000 firms paid $95.7 billion in tax on $3.3 trillion of income.

Singapore Telecom, the parent company of Optus, has not paid company tax in four years despite more than $24 billion in income. Credit: Dominic Lorrimer

But Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel), the parent company to Optus which is under fire over its role in a Triple Zero outage across parts of the country, was not one of them. Despite declaring $8.2 billion in income, it had no taxable income or payable tax.

It’s the fourth successive year that Singtel has declared more than $8 billion in income but not paid company tax. It last paid tax in the 2019-20 when, on income of $9 billion, it declared $181.8 million in taxable income and paid $43 million in tax.

title: Miners shine, sending ASX higher; News Corp slumps
text:
The Australian sharemarket has advanced at the open, led by mining stocks, while Wall Street rose overnight as it brushed off the shutdown of the US government.

The S&P/ASX 200 was 80.8 points, or 0.9 per cent, higher at 8926.50 as of 11.07am AEST, with six of its 11 industry sectors in the green. The Australian dollar was fetching US66.08¢ at 10.45am AEST.

Wall Street continued to power higher, setting the scene for gains on the ASX. Credit: AP

BHP (up 1.5 per cent) clawed back some of Wednesday’s losses even as the escalating row over iron ore exports between the mining giant and China remains unresolved. BHP shares fell 2.5 per cent in the previous session on reports that China’s state-run iron ore buyer China Mineral Resources Group (CMRG) had told major steelmakers and traders to temporarily halt purchases of all new BHP cargoes. BHP chief Mike Henry spoke with Treasurer Jim Chalmers last night to discuss the dispute.

Fellow iron ore heavyweights Fortescue (up 1.2 per cent) and Rio Tinto (up on 0.8 per cent) also advanced.

title: They met every day at the pool for years – until the coffee cup ‘incident’
text:
I love Adrian’s engagement with life. He has lots of energy and belongs to this incredibly artistic circle. He takes his swag out to Balgo [in Western Australia] and Yuendumu [in the Northern Territory] and sleeps under the stars. He even has a fire pit in his backyard, so when artists come from the desert they feel at home.

We started having coffee together every morning after a swim. Neither of us was ever afraid of cold water. The pool temperature can be 16 degrees and we’ll still say it’s beautiful. That’s code for, “It’s frickin’ cold but doable.”

RUSSELL : I was introduced to Adrian in 2008 at the Bondi Icebergs swimming club cafe by a mutual friend and we got on immediately. I thought he was a very cultured individual who could talk to anyone about anything.

Adrian Newstead (left) and Russell Cheek: “When you talk to Russell, you have his undivided attention,” Adrian says. “He listens, he gets your story. It’s very endearing.” Credit: Brent Lewin

Indigenous art dealer Adrian Newstead, 77, and performer/quizmaster Russell Cheek, 73, met at their local swimming pool 17 years ago. They’ve swum there every morning ever since – except when Adrian was banned.

In 2016, he was invited to Paris to show a collection of Indigenous Art Brut. His ability to get things done is just insane. He went to the outback and gathered all these paintings in next to no time. I speak French, so Adrian invited me along to interpret for the exhibition. We had the best time, hanging out in the cafes of the Marais.

Very little about him annoys me, but he does like to complain about his ailments. I just take it all on board. And he’s really bad at texting, especially if he’s travelling. I’ll write to him and won’t hear anything back for four or five days.

He’s got a temper. Last year, new management at the Bergs cafe introduced paper cups, which are bad for the environment and horrible to drink coffee out of. So Adrian brought down his stoneware Tiwi mug. This new manager told him, “You can’t use that because of OH&S.” Adrian said, “I’ve never heard anything so f---ing lame!” The incident got reported to the board and they banned him from the cafe, club and pool for a year. It was eventually commuted to the first day of winter swimming.

‘Adrian often wonders why we never see people in their 80s or beyond swimming here … We’ve vowed to go on for as long as we possibly can.’ Russell Cheek

We don’t disagree about much. We talk about footy and cricket, and art. We exchange views on how beautiful and resourceful the women around us are, and we talk about politics. On election night, me, Adrian and Dave Faulkner from the Hoodoo Gurus got together for a meal and we got Labor over the line.

title: Honda CEO's major car warning as Aussies set to pay more for popular models: 'Very real cost'
text:
Popular models of cars could soon cost much more for Australians to buy if the manufacturer is expected to keep up with a major rule change recently rolled out by the Albanese government, Honda CEO Jay Joseph has warned this week.

There has been a significant push for car manufacturers to meet stricter emissions targets or face hefty fines since the New Vehicle Efficiency Standard (NVES) was rolled out by authorities in July. Joseph claims Honda will inevitably have to increase the price of petrol and hybrid vehicles to cover the cost of fines it will be forced to pay under the NVES. He says the government's pursuit of electric vehicle (EV) uptake is out of step with consumer demand.

"We want to minimise how much we pass that along to consumers, but at some point we can't bear those costs without passing them on to consumers," Joseph told The Australian.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Honda's new car sales are reportedly expected to rise to 75 per cent hybrid next year, but under the NVES, they will likely be above the low emissions threshold set by the government, and partial cost of the fines will need to be absorbed by the consumer.

"Most hybrids, we believe, including ours, will start to be above the compliance threshold next July," he said, pointing to when the government will renew the policy.

Honda boss claims car emissions policy will be counterproductive

Advice provided by independent advisory body Climate Change Authority last month, which informed the government's emission reduction target of 62 to 70 per cent, forecast that half of vehicle sales would need to be electric by 2035. Joseph argues this isn't reflected in buying behaviour, and with the cost of petrol and hybrid cars likely to increase, he believes Australians will simply hold onto their old cars for longer.

"There's a very real possibility that people will buy fewer new cars, and they will keep older vehicles on the road longer because the economics change to the point where it is more viable to invest in repairs and maintenance of older vehicles," he said.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"Older vehicles, by their ­nature, have more emissions. They don't have the ­modern emissions technology, not to mention the safety features and other things that benefit all road users," he said.

"I believe there's a very real cost, real unintended consequence, of people keeping older vehicles on the road longer, which is counter-productive to reducing emissions."

The NVES strongly favours the buying of new electric vehicles. Source: The Australian & Getty

However, Australia is one of the last major countries to introduce vehicle efficiency laws, which has resulted in us becoming a "dumping ground" for the least efficient and most polluting cars, as manufacturers continue to send those cars here, unable to distribute them elsewhere with stricter low-emission policies.

Hussein Dia, a Professor of Future Urban Mobility, told Yahoo News previously that the changes will eventually be positive for Australia, even if not immediately apparent at the start. He said the change will "entice even European manufacturers" to the Australian market.

EV 'range anxiety' continues to be a major concern for drivers

Honda, as well as Mitsubishi, have urged the Australian government to increase funding for charging infrastructure as anxiety over EVs' range continues to create a major obstacle for drivers taking the leap and buying the new technology.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Prospective drivers are concerned they will struggle to find a charger and instead will be limited on where they can travel to, unlike petrol car owners who can rely on an extensive network across the country.

The government has committed $40 million to establish 10,000 new EV public chargers as part of the Transport and Infrastructure Net Zero Roadmap, but warned further investment from the private sector is also needed.

title: Hero who drowned in river tragedy identified
text:
The man who died while trying to help two children struggling in a river has been identified. Tshering Penjor, 38, drowned in the Moore River at Guilderton, about 90km north of Perth, on Tuesday while trying to rescue the kids, Nine News reports.

Mr Penjor was at the popular camping spot with his 13-year-old daughter.

Four swimmers were pulled from the river and paramedics rushed a woman in her 30s to Sir Charles Gardiner Hospital in a critical condition.

Tshering Penjor died on Tuesday while trying to rescue two children. Picture: Supplied

Two girls and a man in his 40s were taken to Joondalup Health Campus, a St John WA spokesman said.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

A fundraiser has been set up for Mr Penjor, a member of the Bhutanese community.

“Tshering was kind and hardworking with dedication towards his others,” GoFundMe organiser Arshdeep Singh said.

“He and his family are in need of our support in return. He has left behind his wife and 13-year-old daughter.

Five ambulance crews attended the scene. Picture: ABC News

Four swimmers were pulled from the water. Picture: ABC News

“His family and friends are experiencing an unimaginable loss which cannot be fulfilled.

“Every donation, no matter the amount, makes a difference.”

As of Thursday morning, the fundraiser had collected more than $2500.

Bhutanese Association president Kinley Tenzin told Nine News that Mr Penjor’s wife was in a “state of shock”.

“She was in a state of shock and then she was saying she cannot believe the situation,” she said.

title: One quiet change is about to let you export much more solar
text:
Australia has more solar panels per person than anywhere else in the world. One in three houses now has rooftop solar.

Our grid operators are working hard to adjust to a new reality where the collective output of rooftop solar is one of our largest sources of power.

Each year there are now a few very sunny days without much electricity demand where there’s so much solar the grid can’t absorb it all. To manage this, grid operators have put a limit on how much of our excess solar we can export to the grid – typically 5 kilowatts per house or as low as 1.5 kW in South Australia. This means households have to limit their solar exports most days of the year.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

But that’s changing. A humble new communication standard gives us a smarter way to manage solar exports so households can export more power, more often, without overloading local networks. The standard – known as the Australian Common Smart Inverter Profile – is a set of rules for how inverters and other devices communicate with the grid operator.

It may sound small, but these new rules could have very large benefits to households and the grid. For instance, it will mean South Australia’s 1.5 kW limit can grow to 10 kW when the local grid has capacity – which is most of the time.

Solar arrays are on one in three Australian homes. We could make even more use of this common technology. Douglas Cliff/Getty

Why we need to shift to a smarter grid

Around 40% of what Australians pay for power is due to the cost of past grid-building. Billions have been spent over the last 20 years to enable the grid to respond to the growth in peak demand – the few hours a year when demand could outstrip supply, potentially causing blackouts.

As we electrify homes and transport, total electricity demand could roughly double.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The good news is our solar panels, home batteries and electric vehicles are a very useful way to meet this rising demand and use the existing grid more efficiently. Over time, this should mean power bills finally stop rising. Some estimates suggest they will fall 20% over the next decade.

Rooftop solar is going from strength to strength. Globally speaking, Australia is behind on EV uptake but catching up. The new federal subsidy has supercharged the home battery market. Installations have shot from about 200 to 1,000 a day. Heat pumps and electric hot water systems are more and more popular.

Solar panels, electric vehicles and home batteries can be used to avoid expensive grid upgrades. Raja Islam/Getty

The grid isn’t full

It’s common to assume the power grid is under strain. But in reality, we’re only using 43% of its capacity.

That means we can run a lot more through the same poles and wires if we time things better. It would cause much less strain on the grid if electric hot-water heaters, heat pumps and EVs are set to charge during the middle of the day, when solar is abundant.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

With this new standard in place, Australia should be able to avoid some expensive grid upgrades. Recent analysis shows better coordination of our household electricity resources could avoid the need to spend billions on new grid infrastructure such as transmission lines.

What are the challenges?

The new standard will make a rapid and noticeable difference to how much solar householders can export overall. But it won’t be the same everywhere.

A street at the end of a long rural line, with lots of rooftop solar and little daytime demand, will hit export limits sooner than a short urban line near a substation. Some households will be asked to reduce solar output more often than others, which raises fairness concerns.

Our research group is running trials to find fairer ways of allocating grid capacity and to ensure everyone benefits from smart-grid technology.

There’s also the question of trust. Some people may not feel comfortable letting their power company adjust their devices remotely and may choose to stick with limited solar exports. (Solar arrays can still be shut off remotely in an extreme grid event). Only 43% of energy consumers surveyed trust electricity companies to “do the right thing”.

Clearer protections will be essential as Australia’s electricity system grows more diverse, decentralised and complex. As more energy companies offer incentives to households to access the power stored in their EV and household batteries, regulations must be in place to ensure clarity over how much profit is shared with customers.

Standard and deliver

For Australia’s solar households, this new communication standard will be a boon.

But expanding solar exports is the easy part. Securing public trust in the new two-way communication system will require clear messaging, enforceable protections, transparency and visible household benefits.
